questions.questionText: A team of naval engineers is designing a new research submarine. Its total mass is $!$150,000\,\text{kg}$!$ when its ballast tanks are empty, and its total internal volume (which includes the ballast tanks and all other internal spaces that would be submerged) is $!$180\,\text{m}^3$!$. To achieve neutral buoyancy, they need to take in seawater with a density of $!$1025\,\text{kg/m}^3$!$. Calculate the exact mass of seawater, in $!$\text{kg}$!$, that needs to be pumped into the ballast tanks so that the submarine's average density becomes equal to the seawater density.

steps.stepText: Let's start by recalling the relationship between mass, volume, and density. Identify the correct formula that relates the overall density ($!$\rho$!$) of the submarine to its mass ($!$m$!$) and volume ($!$V$!$).

Now, considering that for neutral buoyancy the submarine’s overall density must match that of seawater, set up the equation where the total mass after adding the water divided by the volume equals the seawater density. First, calculate the product of the seawater density and the submarine's volume, i.e., compute $!$1025\,\text{kg/m}^3 \times 180\,\text{m}^3$!$.

Great, now that you have the required total mass for neutral buoyancy, determine the mass of seawater needed by subtracting the empty mass of the submarine from this total mass. Calculate $!$184500 - 150000$!$.

questions.questionText: A logging company is transporting timber down a river. The pine timber has a density of $!$0.65\ \text{g/cm}^3$!$. Convert this density to $!$\text{kg/m}^3$!$.

steps.stepText: Let's begin by identifying the conversion factor needed to change density from $!$\text{g/cm}^3$!$ to $!$\text{kg/m}^3$!$. Which of the following conversion factors is correct?

Now that you've identified the correct conversion factor, apply it to find the density in $!$\text{kg/m}^3$!$. Multiply the given density $!$0.65\ \text{g/cm}^3$!$ by the conversion factor you selected.
